messageBody:
I'm just getting started using JUnit to test a Swing application.
In my test case I want to manipulate the GUI, eg simulate button
clicks etc. (really I want to invoke the commands the buttons
represent). How can my test case find an instance of the GUI objects
to call? I tried having a static variable that contains the last GUI
screen instance, but this is null inside my test case whereas it
returns a non-null instance when accessed from
my non-Junit code immediately before that.
Am I doing something silly that causes the static access to return
null? My startup code IS a bit "funky" for historical reasons.
Or is there a better way of going about running test cases in GUI
apps?

I'm using JUnit 3.5 with JDK 1.3 on Windows NT. No IDEs.

Thanks,

Dave Nixon
Annuncio Software
dnixon@...

Boiled down my code looks roughly like:

Application.java:
public class Application extends GenericApplication
{
// starts here
static public void main(String[] args)
{
GenericApplication.self = new Application();
self.runApp();
}
}

GenericApplication.java:
public static GenericApplication self; // only ever one instance

public void runApp()
{
// create GUI panels etc, then
screen.setVisible(true);

// GenericApplication.self is non-null here
// run tests
String testArgs[] = new String[] { "full.path.of.MyTest" };
testRunner = new TestRunner();
testRunner.start(testArgs);

// MyTest case runs but references to GenericApplication.self
// from within test case are null
}

MyTest.java:

import GenericApplication;
public class MyTest extends TestCase
{
public MyTest(String name) {
super(name);
}

public void testSomething()
{
// GenericApplication.self is null here
}
}
